comments.commentBody: Please provide examples of 'unjust immigration laws'  in respect of how they affect illegal immigrants who,  by definition are breaking the law.

It is great to hear that California is taking these steps, even thought Trump has already said that he only will deport criminals. (Of course, what Trump says and does are two different things) Not to mention the fact that the agriculture industry, which has supported Trump, needs many of the workers that would be deported under a mass deportation, as does Kobach's Kansas. In Trump's America, more liberal states should shield their people from the federal government.

While everyone is so busy rallying to make America great again, they should have also thought to mix in some science and engineering classes because my neighborhood is filled with engineers and computer scientists born abroad who came here to bring us their incredible talents that we haven't managed to create enough of here. Many of them are feeling a little less rosey about America these days even though their immigration status is secure. they are fearing for their personal safety and how they will be treated in Trumps America where so many embrace hate and xenophobia.  I don't see many of these people at trumps rallies retraining to become  Ruby on Rails engineers any time soon so they better hope they don't alienate all these incredible foreign talents from coming here or they will only continue to accelerate Americas decline.

People seem to forget that those children are largely citizens despite the immigration status of their parents.   There is a monumental demographic shift underway in this country that will soon see the end of a non- Hispanic white majority  and deportation will not change that.  The xenophobes and racists might have won a temporary victory, but in the long run everyone will have to find a way to live in a pluralistic America with no one group in the majority and places like California will be on the leading edge of those changes.

There is a huge amount of hysteria and whipped up right wing nonsense about immigrants out there. Yes we need some controls in place. But the notion that we are being invaded daily by hordes of immigrants as trump would have us believe is false. Most immigrants are not criminals. Most immigrants pay taxes, work hard , add money to the economy.
Immigrant labor has made this country rich.
We are a nation of immigrants trump included and his wife and if we were honest about who this country REALLY. Belongs to, we would give it back to the Indians and Mexicans. Immigrants are human beings just like you and me.

"But states and cities that value immigrants, including the undocumented...". The opening of the second paragraph of this editorial illustrates the fundamental dishonesty of The NY Times editorial board and the left. To write an entire essay on immigration that alludes those who are unlawfully as part of a bigger problem is as false ad fake as Hillary Clinton and her State Department blaming Benghazi on a YouTube video. There is no issue with lawfully present immigrants. Period. Full stop. Neither Mr. Trump nor the Republicans have ever suggested otherwise. If one wants to understand why there cannot be a reasonable discussion on unlawful presence in the US, the opening of this Editorial lays it out for all to see.

Finally the issue wasn't brought about originally as a "failure to reform " our laws. It was a failure to enforce the laws in the first place.

Laws that cause for the separation of families are unjust. Ripping parents from their children are violations of morality and therefore unjust. The cold hearts of avaricious conservatives are threatening the fabric of America. We are the result of the assimilation of immigrants.

I find it interesting that the term undocumented is used. They are illegal and they are here because we do not enforce our laws. If you want to change the law to allow them to stay that is fine with me but do not choose which laws to enforce and which not to enforce. That is what some of this election was about and generalizing that white people with this point of view are White nationalists is a little naive. Maybe we should not have a border and welcome all the people from the Middle east, North Africa and anywhere else into our country. I am sure California has the jobs and affordable housing for all of them.
I'm proud of California and glad it's part of our country.  If anyone can lead the Trump resistance, they can.

"General Kelly, who led the United States Southern Command, warned Congress last year of the danger of terrorists and “weapons of mass destruction” coming in from Mexico. He admitted he had no evidence, but was clanging the alarm all the same."

How typical of Trump, his appointees, and the critical-thinking-challenged horde that voted for him. No evidence, but say it loud and often and it becomes true.

As a public school teacher in Los Angeles, I'm proud to say that my union, the United Teachers of Los Angeles, has also declared that we will take no part in cooperating with any efforts at deportation. Nor will my district as a whole.

Trump and his wrecking crew can have the entire country between the coasts. Our state government in California believes in the Constitution, and unlike Trump we've read it.

Perhaps if we annoy Trump enough, he'll kick us out of the union. I hope so.

Most actually came legally, and became "illegal" due to overstayed visas or never having had the documents with which to apply for citizenship in the first place.

Why don't you come to my school and tell my students, most of whom either don't have any papers themselves or have at least one parent/aunt/uncle/grandparent who has no papers, that they or their families are less worthy of an education or a life free from the corruption and danger that they fled in places like Salvador and Guatemala. Seriously. Look them in the eye and tell them they deserve to be put on a bus that will let them out in the middle of an effective war zone. Tell them they should never see their parents again. Tell them their grandmother, who works 50 hours a week cleaning homes at age 70, should be sent back to the blood-soaked hills outside Acapulco.

Or maybe a little humanity and recognition of the fact that illegal immigration has a net-neutral effect on our economy is a better option.

@ Mark Thomason,

Focusing on California is a geographic misreading of the election results. Urban, city-centric America gave Hillary the popular victory over the rural Republican regions, and that includes election results within Michigan no less than California.

The electoral college is unnecessary to assert democracy - the House of Representatives adequately accomplishes that task, and the Senate is tilted sharply in favor or rural regions. Adding the rural-biased electoral college to the mix gives an unjustifiable preponderance of power to rural regions. It is urban areas, where the majority of We the People live that have are effectively discriminated against and need defending in this unjust system.

For all you arm chair agriculturalists out there, I actually have experience hiring "migrant workers" and "locals" in an agricultural setting. My family orchard would have quickly collapsed without them. I tried hiring "locals" who were laid off or who had happened onto hard times. This work is way too tough for the great preponderance of Americans -- even young healthy ones. I personally attempted to teach each local hire how to handle fruit and how to do the job correctly. (The migrant workers needed no instruction)
My experience is that our "migrant workers" were not only hard working, dependable, likeable, and refreshing to be around, they also were motivated, for whatever reason, to pick our fruit so that it was marketable as a US #1 grade product. As far as I know, none of the migrants were criminals.
Those locals? They whined, loafed, cussed, stole picking cards from other pickers, bruised the fruit, and picked up drops from the ground claiming that everything was picked from the tree. They turned my quality fruit into cider apples.
I had to let most locals go. The ones I kept (maybe 1 out of 20) I moved to the soft jobs -- driving tractor, pressing cider, or something similar.
I am convinced that no matter what I paid the locals my fruit (and therefore my orchard) would not have survived with their capabilities. Sometimes reality sets in.
You want affordable produce in your grocery?

No one is discussing the potential fall of the economy if this segment of our labor force is removed. It's not just in California where undocumented workers are essential, but especially here, where massive amounts of our food is produced and done so cheaply precisely b/c there is immigrant labor. And I'm surprised at how little empathy there is for undocumented immigrants who have raised families here and who could face separation from their children and worse. More compassion is in order.

For all the people who want the law enforced, here's a thought:  hold accountable the corporations that employ people illegally.  Corporations have to have legal corporate licenses in order to operate - and those licenses are held in cities and towns. If cities and towns want to protest, start looking up where these corporations have their corporate charters and start agitating for revocation of those licenses/charters. (I am sure a lawyer can explain this better than I can, but I know this is possible).

Seems we are in the pre-Civil War era with Northern States refusing to enforce the fugitive return part of the Constitution with respect to escaped slaves from the plantations of the South.  Hopefully, we will not have another Sherman march to the sea in California.

Good for California. But their stance is filled with cynicism. After all, their agriculture depends on migrant workers. And here is where the cynicism kicks in: These workers are too often grossly underpaid, non-unionized, given squalor-level/substandard housing, and working under harsh conditions amounting to servitude/quasi-slavery. Some sanctuary.
We are a nation of laws. Laws even California must follow.
The old "States Rights" argument, huh? Interesting change of perspective.
Immigrants must come legally.  Period.

What nonsense.  Families who came here illegally can choose to go home together.  When citizen children are old enough to care for themselves they can come back.  That in itself is something.  I am not an "avaricious conservative" and I want our immigration laws followed.

Nazi Germany was a nation of laws as well. Unless we stand up to the unethical  and immoral behavior of President Trump, we are no better than he is. He won the election demonizing various groups, including immigrants and Muslims, whom white men could blame for their troubles. Unfortunately, this is a tried and true technique and much easier than offering real solutions. ( Notice Don the Con' s cabinet appointments are against expanding health insurance, Medicare, raising the minimum wage, etc. ). These are dark days in America.

It's quite unbelievable reading this:

"Nobody yet knows what Donald Trump will do to immigration enforcement"-a pretty good guess is that he will at lest BEGIN to ENFORCE.

"But states and cities value immigrants, including the undocumented.." I don't know a single person, many of whom are very, very conservative, who doesn't cherish this country's immigrant history, not one. They do, however, make distinctions between "documented" and "undocumented" immigrants. The fact that political correctness bans the term "illegal immigrant" highlights the problem.

Mr. Trump long ago stopped saying that he would favor deporting all "undocumented" immigrants, realizing no doubt that it would be nigh impossible to do this. But he did, wisely in my view, hold to the belief that we should deport "undocumented" immigrants who have criminal records. Inferring that these cities "understand that not all unauthorized immigrants are criminals," tries to give the impression that Mr. Trump does not understand this. He does, and so do his supporters.

To once gain whip up the view that dealing with this issue through enforcement is solely coming from "nativist ideologues and white nationalists" is absurd.

I suggest that the NYT editorial board take a nationwide listening tour. I suggest 2-3 months. Perhaps some new perspective and balance would result.

Using the term "immigrants" is misleading. Trump, as much as I may dislike him, has never suggested that immigrants who are here legally should be deported. He has been very specific that he intends to deport "illegal immigrants" or if you prefer foreign nationals who are here illegally.
I raise this point because as much as people may think it's ok to be less that truthful or "specific" on this point they are not doing their cause any favors with American who feel that immigration laws should be Enforced whether the illegal immigrant is from Norway on an expired visa or a South American who has been smuggled across the border.

Liberals, of which I am one, who failed to capture the House or Senate should take a a deep breath and consider how their hyperbolic rhetoric and often Janus like promises has damaged their credibility and their chances of bringing others on board.

Deciding that you or your state will decide what the laws will be is a dangerous strategy...ultimately it means there are no laws good or bad because if someone decides their end is "good" the means are good too. I would have thought we had had enough do that.

As a Californian, as a descendant of immigrants, and as a Democrat, I 100% OPPOSE the obsessive focus of California Democrats on defending illegal immigrants. They and you, the editorial board, refuse to acknowledge the distinction between legal immigrants (who followed the rules) and those who didn't.

Yes, 1 in 4 Californians is foreign born, but far fewer than that are here illegally. I don't support Trump's mass deportation plans, but it is outrageous that taxpayer dollars may be used to fund free lawyers to defend illegal immigrants. No other country extends so many rights and state funded benefits to people who deliberately stay illegally.

Meanwhile, there are other parts of the Trump agenda that affect many more Californian citizens and legal immigrants (such as repealing our health insurance through the ACA). The Democrat leadership of our state should be focused on defending us against those parts of the agenda.
